column1:
Bobcats are proud adventurers::: discoverers::: scholars::: and community members. They are now and #TXSTnext: www.txstate.edu/next

"#TXST gave me confidence to pursue a career I wanted. Being a Hispanic woman & trying to be a part of a male-dominant industry is such a challenge::: but my time here taught me I'm just as equally capable." - Evelyn H. (BS CSM '21)

"It was the only school I applied to just because I loved Texas State so much." - Brandon D. (Performance Production::: Spring 2023)

"I fell in love with #TXST as a sophomore in high school. I'm just so glad that I went with my heart & chose #TXST::: the place that I felt the most comfortable & wanted to be at." - Shelby C. (Electronic Media & Mass Comm::: Spring 2021)

“My first time on campus was for my student orientation::: but when I got here::: it felt like home.” - Javaun B. (Theatre::: Senior)

We are 1 week away from Step Up for State! This is the opportunity for you::: our entire Bobcat family::: to impact the people::: programs::: and places you care most about at TXST. On October 26 and 27::: you’ll have 1:::899 minutes to pick your passion and make a gift that creates the NEXT big thing.

Learn more at stepup.txstate.edu

Bobcat Days are back! Come see what makes #TXST so unique from the rest of Texas universities! On October 16::: you can explore campus::: get information about academics::: housing::: and everything in between::: while you find your new home in San Marcos!

Find more information here: https://www.admissions.txstate.edu/visit/events/bobcat-day.html

On October 8::: Texas State University publicly launched NEXT IS NOW::: the largest fundraising campaign in university history. The campaign is on track to raise $250 million to advance initiatives focused on student success and becoming a Tier 1 research university. #TXSTnext

NEWS.TXSTATE.EDU
Texas State University launches NEXT IS NOW capital campaign

Are you ready::: #TXST21? Summer Commencement is this Friday! Here are our tips for a great day:
✔️ Dress comfortably
✔️ Plan a meeting spot for after the ceremony
✔️ Make sure your diploma is right-side up for photos
✔️ Empty pockets and secure your #TXST ring BEFORE you jump in the river!

What is your advice for our newest TXST graduates?
column3:
Reign in on your gratefulness on all the memories::: strife::: and battles that led you to this successful moment!
I wore my bathing suit under my gown. I had fixed my hair and face nicely::: but I straight up did not care at all what I looked like underneath (that’s what the party is for afterwards). When I jumped in the SM River::: so close to its headwaters::: I felt baptized::: like a spiritual cleansing took place. Whether you’re a woman or a dude::: or young or old::: I highly recommend jumping in the river.
Texas State was a huge blessing for me::: and the geography department was an even greater one. ❤️
✨Sending light and love to all the new graduates! Eat ‘em up::: Cats! 🐾
column4:

Texas State's Dr. William Chittenden recently investigated a topic that could potentially affect millions of Americans — the canceling of student debt. With policymakers putting forth forgiveness proposals and President Biden "prepared to write off a $10:::000 debt:::" what does this mean for the nation's economy::: and who would benefit most? Dr. Chittenden answers these questions and more.

THECONVERSATION.COM
Canceling student loan debt will barely boost the economy::: but a targeted approach could help certain groups
column3: Or we could all remember that this debt wasn’t forced on these people and they could be adults and pay it back like the rest of us did. Y’all act like this is the governments fault for these people asking for a loan. Give me a break.
column4: Biden said "nothing will fundamentally change." It's the only promise he will keep. There will be no student debt cancellation::: no $15 minimum wage and no Public Option::: even though he campaigned on all of these things. Lip service doesn't mean much when you don't deliver on promises. Let's also not forget that Biden was the one who directly contributed to creating the student debt problem. I will believe it when I see it.
column5: $400 a month? He makes it sound like that’s supposed to be small. That’s the same number that half of all Americans can’t handle if it were an unexpected cost. Imagine giving that money back to those people!
column6:
The biggest thing we should learn from this is that college is in fact too expensive.

There should also be protections for borrowers just with any other loan and part of the fight is to obtain bankruptcy as an option for borrowers who’s lives are literally ruined because of student loans.

There should also be protections on interest rates because some people end up in a loop where they barely pay anything over interest and their loans stay stagnant meaning they will NEVER pay off their loans regardless of their payments.

I would love for student loans to be forgiven. But it’s really only acceptable if we can stop viewing college students and grads as people who “chose” to be indebted.

Many of you complain that high school doesn’t teach you about economics or credit cards or finances.

Maybe that’s why we can understand that 17-18 year olds going to college are victims here because they were unaware of the repercussions of what they agreed to pay back.

If you can’t see that MANY students were taken advantage of here then that’s why you’re struggling to see why this is important.

I don’t care if student loans get forgiven. I’ll keep paying regardless::: but even I can recognize that many kids are taken advantage of by the student loan system and people are profiting off of their lack of knowledge.

Even more so::: you’re speaking of a generation who saw mostly no other option.

The enemy isn’t borrowers or students. It’s predatory student loans and overly expensive tuition.

Don’t forgive student loans::: but protect the borrowers like you would with any other loan. Especially when these borrowers were completely unaware of how the student loan system works and were provided little to no information about how they work until after borrowing.
column7: Yet the universities keep jacking up the cost to attend

Study.com names Texas State's advertising degree among best in nation
column3: This isn’t about the advertising program but the ESSS program. My daughter has had an amazing senior year! One of her profs knew every students’ name by the first 3 classes and referred to them by name the rest of the semester. Then at the end of the semester he called each one up and had a 1:1 conversation about the class and their future. This was huge in my books. Another prof (Walker) sent my daughter an email that brought me to tears after she did well and got an A in his class. She gets A&Bs but has never stood out for her academics. He commended her on her work in his class and offered to be of help if she decided to pursue a Masters. It was something she will cherish from her time at TxSt

column1:
NEWS.TXSTATE.EDU
Jessica T. Brown champions mission to expand BIPOC access to environmentalism

Texas State Alumni Association
20 April::: 07:03 ·

This week::: we celebrate Earth Day. Alumna Jessica T. Brown (B.S. '18)::: who grew up in Houston::: learned about nature's power through experience. 🌎

“Houston moves through everything I do:::” Brown says. The combination of her family valuing outdoor time::: her experiences with flooding::: and the growing conversation about climate change impacted the alumna during her formative years and led to her passion for environmentalism.

This summer::: Brown is launching Fernland Studios::: a nonprofit organization that reimagines environmentalism through art and education. Jessica's vision includes offering scholarships to Black::: Indigenous::: and people of color to work within artist residencies::: educational retreats::: and writing workshops.

McCoy College of Business at Texas State University
19 April::: 05:33 ·

It's officially Business Leadership Week::: Bobcats! We are kicking off the week with a professional development seminar from People With Purpose Founder & CEO::: Danielle Duell. In this session::: she will cover how to have a purposeful career plan in a dynamic world & provide guidance on next steps to secure your ideal next role and embark.

📅 Online::: 5pm

column3: There are so many "Stunt" teachers::: teaching for the glory::: not for their students and bad administrators have already destroyed our archaic leaning form of teaching in this current system of over rewarded "Stunt" teachers. The best teachers do not pull stunts for fame and recognition::: they roll up their sleeves and get personally involved in the mundane daily tasks and disciplined development of as many of their students as they can. They have precious little time for pulling a stunt for time consuming "fame". They are seldom popular enough(too honest and too busy) to have buildings named after them and most administrators will only tolerate them because they are real workhorses::: always there-always doing most of the real work::: always adding the newest tools as fast as she can to her already hefty bag of tools; she is too busy actually teaching and studying her current group of students to master THEIR learning quirks-she has nearly no time to politically smooze administrators and others in power positions. Because she encourages and TEACHES especially the "lowest" of her students::: too::: you won't hear the names of your best teachers in popular::: admiring circles until MAYBE many::: many years later(if students can still even recall her name and not just that they learned a lot from her) from mature students who finally understand what a real gift she was to their education::: personally.

column1:
Campus-operations update:

All classes in-person & virtual are canceled until 8 am on Wednesday::: Feb. 24. We know our community is dealing with the aftermath of the storm & we want to provide all Bobcats time to recover. The Dean of Students Office is busy setting up support services for students impacted by the storm. We will provide more updates as soon as these services become available.

TXST offices will be open on Monday::: Feb. 22::: to support our students. Staff supervisors will communicate with employees about their availability to work in the office or from home. We appreciate the many staff members that have worked around the clock to support our students.

On Feb. 20::: these San Marcos campus buildings will open at noon & close at normal times:

Alkek Library
The Rec Center
LBJ Student Center

*We're currently checking for damage & hours of operation may change. The Round Rock Campus will follow regular hours this weekend.

The Student Health Center will be open Feb. 19 from noon to 4 pm to provide walk-in/urgent care services. Ask-A-Nurse services are available when the SHC is closed. Persons requiring emergency care should dial 9-1-1 for assistance. SHC temporary phone #: 737.213.9377

Dining Services is working to expand dining hours & options for this weekend. We will provide updates when new hours & dining options become available. Food & non-drinkable water are available at the VFW in San Marcos (1701 Hunter Rd) for off-campus students.

Shuttles will resume service tomorrow::: Feb. 20::: including the route to Target & other retail stores.

column1:
Food On Campus:

Hot::: to-go meals are available for ANY student with their student ID at Harris Dining Hall (700 Moore St::: San Marcos) and Commons Dining Halls (109 Bobcat Trail::: San Marcos) from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. through Monday::: Feb. 22. Any student who presents a valid student ID will receive a hot to-go meal regardless of whether you have a meal plan or not.

Because the university dining halls are also impacted by the rolling blackouts::: dine-in meals inside the dining halls aren’t an option at this time. When conditions improve and we begin to receive food deliveries again from our suppliers::: we will open additional dining halls and locations.

The Bobcat Shuttle parked for warming at Bobcat Village has snacks available for Bobcat Village residents dealing with power and water outages.

column3: My son was miserable in his dorm. Its was 45 degrees in his dorm room. Evacuated at night due to false alarm and told to go back in hour later but still no power or water to warm up. Food at dinning facility non existent. Lines so long they had to stand for over an hour in the cold again just to get cold food. What does the school provide a bus to keep warm but they can't stay in there long and my son has to walk over 30 mins in cold to get there to warm up::: ridiculous. I'm all about letting my boy fend for himself but this was uncalled for. I bet the president was nice and warm in her house. Leadership should have been out there cooking::: BBQ ing something for these students. Lead by example::: take care of your people. I am extremely disappointed on how Texas State handled this. Finally had to pick up my son to keep him from freezing and going hungry.
column4: When will power and water be restored to the dorms? Blanco in particular?
column5: You're too late Texas State! Shame on y'all! My daughter and her best friend froze OUTSIDE Bobcat Village in freezing temps due to y'alls negligence!!! Then you tell them they have to stay in a covid wing if they can't find shelter!
column6: Thank you Texas State University personnel doing what can be be done under the circumstances. I know you have families too that you are worried about.
column7:
Well::: our daughter is there. No car. We live 5 hours away. I was searching for a hotel room for her and she said::: "Mom::: the hotels can lose electricity and water too." (Was this a tiny bit of common sense I had not thought of?) She said she was layered up and she was fine. She said when electricity came on sporadically that's when she would quickly cook food. (Was this a second sign of intelligent life peeking through?) We all know when our feet are freezing it makes things 1000% worse; so I told her to put on fuzzy socks (the ones I wanted to burn to keep her from wearing them in public last year) then put gallon ziplok bags on her feet::: then a second pair of ugly fuzzy socks. My tiny piece of advice to save her 72 hour uncomfortablene
ss in college. She never has taken my advice before ('cause she has known everything since she turned 13) but I think she might have just listened to me this time. She called me today to tell me about this post. That tells me she has survived::: figured out a way to keep her cell phone charged and wasn't whining or complaining about any of the stuff I read on this thread. Was she actually listening to us the past 4 years and just pretending not to? Hmmmm?? Well::: I hope some of the other kids shared their parent's tips with her::: cause I never told her to melt ice for water if she ran out. Oops! 🤣🤣

column1:
A message from President Denise Trauth

Dear Bobcat Parents and Guardians:::

I want to personally say that I am deeply concerned about the well-being of our students during this very challenging weather event occurring in Texas. The safety of our students is our top priority::: and we are doing everything in our power with the resources available to address their needs.

- Our Housing staff are on-site in affected residence halls to monitor conditions and help students to stay warm.
- We cannot open other large indoor spaces on our campuses such as the University Events Center or LBJ Student Center for warming centers because they are also impacted by the rolling blackouts.
- University Dining can only provide to-go meal options through Harris and Commons dining halls from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. daily.
- Two shuttles are located at the Lantana Bus Stop::: and two are at the corner of Reed and Moore Streets near Blanco Hall. The shuttles are available overnight::: but we ask students to not plan on spending all night on the busses. All COVID-19 safety precautions::: including wearing a face covering::: must be followed in the shuttles.
- We are working to restore several disrupted networks::: including the university-wide phone system.

Students living off-campus in San Marcos can find information about local warming stations and shelter at these links:

City of San Marcos News Flash - bit.ly/2NADwrQ
Hays County News & Alerts - bit.ly/3av1Lks

Our university staff is working around the clock to provide critical services to our students.
column3: Thank you for your genuine concern for the well-being of all the students::: as a mom of a Bobcat I truly appreciate all you are trying to do during these unprecedented times..stay safe all!

I don’t want to hear excuses for why you can’t do more... I want to you implement a comprehensive emergency plan to take care of the kids you force to live in these dorms.

We understand::: but the conditions and situations these young students are going through are simply unacceptable!..
.we're so mad right now!::: on Thursday morning around 1:00 am our son was evacuated from his dorm and told to go to the nearest dorm which is at least a 10 min walk since the dorms around him were being evacuated as well. It was 28°F with freezing rain on top of it::: and they were told to leave their dorms!!!!? which by the way we still don't know exactly WHY!? It's already bad enough the State dropped the ball by not properly planning for this winter weather that was forecasted::: but it's also clear that TXST University didn't have a plan A or even a plan B for that matter!. The University needs to do better for it's students and not leave them to fend for themselves during these extraordinary circumstances! TXST University you need to do better for our kids!

column1:
Texas State University will be closed through 8 a.m. Saturday::: February 20 due to inclement weather and continued power outages which have impacted multiple university systems::: including phone lines and computer networks. All classes and events are canceled::: including virtual/online classes and events. University offices will remain closed. Only designated critical personnel should report to work on the campuses.

Faculty are asked to continue to communicate with their students directly on any alternate class plans.

The university will continue to monitor weather and road conditions::: and will announce the operational status of our campuses beyond 8 a.m. on Saturday no later than Friday::: February 19 at 5 p.m.

TXSTATE.EDU
Texas State University

Texas State University will be closed through Wednesday::: February 17::: at 8:00 AM due to inclement weather. All classes and events are canceled including virtual/online classes and events. Only designated essential personnel should report to work on the campuses.

Faculty will communicate with their students directly on any alternate class plans. The provost will send a follow-up message to faculty later this afternoon.

The university will continue to monitor weather and road conditions::: and will announce the operational status of our campuses beyond Wednesday at 8:00 AM no later than Tuesday::: February 16 at 5:00 PM.

Safety & Emergency Communications

Common Experience at Texas State
18 January::: 12:55 ·

The legacies of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King::: Jr. and President Lyndon B. Johnson will forever be connected. Dr. King was America’s most prominent leader of the Civil Rights Movement. He is widely remembered for his “I Have a Dream” speech from the Lincoln Memorial::: for his “Letter from Birmingham Jail:::” and for his direction of nonviolent protest and resistance. His leadership and inspiration were keys to the passage of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Voting Rights Act in 1965::: both of which were signed into law by President Johnson. In a stirring speech to Congress on March 15::: 1965::: pressing for passage of the Voting Rights Act::: President Johnson emphasized Dr. King’s words::: stating that “it’s all of us who must overcome the crippling legacy of bigotry and injustice. And we shall overcome.”

The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King was awarded the 1964 Nobel Peace Prize for his nonviolent activism against racial inequality and injustice. In his acceptance speech::: he said: "I accept this award on behalf of a civil rights movement which is moving with determination and a majestic scorn for risk and danger to establish a reign of freedom and a rule of justice. […] After contemplation::: I conclude that this award which I receive on behalf of that movement is a profound recognition that nonviolence is the answer to the crucial political and moral question of our time – the need for man to overcome oppression and violence without resorting to violence and oppression. […] I believe that unarmed truth and unconditional love will have the final word."

Dr. King was assassinated in Memphis::: Tennessee::: on April 4::: 1968. He was just 39 years old.

Lyndon B. Johnson was 36th President of the United States. He is Texas State University’s most distinguished alumnus::: having graduated in 1930. He earned the university’s first Distinguished Alumnus award in 1959.

Martin Luther King::: Jr. Day is a federal holiday celebrating his life and legacy::: observed on the third Monday of January each year.

On Tuesday::: January 19::: the Texas State University community will celebrate the life and legacy of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King::: Jr. in an online presentation::: 4-5 pm. Register: bit.ly/3nQIjBT

TUE::: JAN 19
37th Annual Martin Luther King Jr. Celebration

MON::: NOV 9::: 2020
Diversity Week: Moving from Words to Action

Common Experience at Texas State
8 November 2020 г.::: 11:35 ·

On Nov. 8::: 1965::: President Lyndon B. Johnson returned to his alma mater::: Texas State University (then Southwest Texas State College)::: to sign the Higher Education Act. It initiated TRIO Programs and opened doors of opportunity for young people. In his remarks that day::: he reflected on his time as a student:

"Here the seeds were planted from which grew my firm conviction that for the individual::: education is the path to achievement and fulfillment; for the Nation::: it is a path to a society that is not only free but civilized; and for the world::: it is the path to peace — for it is education that places reason over force."

On Monday::: Nov. 9::: 2020::: the Common Experience and the LBJ Distinguished Lecture Series presents an online conversation with John Quiñones::: a TRIO/Upward Bound alumnus::: ABC News veteran::: and creator/host of "What Would You Do?" The event will open three simultaneous celebrations — First-Generation Week::: Diversity Week::: and Mass Communication Week — as we reflect on the 55th anniversary of the Higher Education Act and President Johnson's legacy in education. ✯

Information and FREE registration:
https://bit.ly/2IgO9NQ

We are saddened by the loss of Jerry Jeff Walker. Our deepest condolences to the family of this legendary Texas musician.

We are forever grateful for the gifts he provided to The Wittliff Collections. His stories and music will live on.

Texas State University
15 September 2017 г.::: 11:42 ·

Legendary Texas music artist Jerry Jeff Walker has donated his archive to The Wittliff Collections. Walker’s archive is a major acquisition for the newly-formed Texas Music Collection and comprises more than 100 boxes of materials spanning Walker’s entire career::: featuring master tapes::: photographs::: hand-written lyrics and artifacts.

Save the date! On October 7-8::: 2020::: Texas State University will host its fifth annual day of giving – Step Up for State. This year::: the 2020 Step Up for State campaign will feature student-focused funds for Texas State University’s Big Ideas: Learning with AR/VR::: Translational Health::: Materials with Intelligence::: Harnessing Big Data::: and Innovation & Entrepreneurship. For 1:::899 minutes::: the entire Bobcat community will come together to support mission-critical projects from across our university. In the last four years::: our loyal Bobcat community has helped raise over $900:::000 to support Texas State University. Click the link to learn more about how you can Step Up for State: https://stepup.txstate.edu/
Time passes but we will never forget. We remember the ones we lost & honor the heroes whose courage was unwavering 19 years ago today.

column1:
TXST is revising the fee structure for online & hybrid classes to meet the needs of our students dealing with financial difficulties as a result of COVID-19. This change will waive more than $7 million in fees for our Bobcats.

Learn more: bit.ly/3gupnGt
column3:
Students who signed up for online courses do so with the contractual understanding that they must pay the 'Electronic' (online) course fee. Students who register for in-residence (live instruction) classes do so with the understanding that there will be no additional::: unadvertised/
hidden costs. If TXST makes changes to the class format after students have registered::: with the requirement that students must pay a penalty fee resulting from that format change::: how is this different than any other business (TXST/all colleges are businesses) adding a fee/cost to a previously contracted purchase of a good or service? Universities routinely enjoy considerable latitude in the way they add "additional fees" at billing to advertised costs::: however this issue does not follow the "operational costs" rationale normally embraced. When TXST elected (they were not mandated) to change course formatting to online::: they should bear any associated fiscal or physical challenges.

column5: My daughter told me she only have 1 classroom course and the rest online but::: I haven't seen any fees "Waived" 🤔. Will check back on her account again.
column6: Texas State I am so disappointed in you especially how you have handled the covid situation in regards to students and their online classes. I know of multiple universities who have actually given students the OPTION of wanting to take classes online or in person. You don’t give them an option and now you want to make them pay more!? This doesn’t make you look any better! All your doing is scamming students! Next time I get asked if students should attend Texas State I will gladly say no! It’s a beautiful campus::: I’ve had amazing memories here but Texas State as a school is trash!
column7: Hi all::: my friend::: her family and one of my relatives are just diagnosed wiyh coronavirus last week. I feel it is speading out faster than ever. I feel really unsafe going back to normal classes even I miss the campus so badly. I registered all classes for in-person teaching and then I got emails from school switching all of those to online without any of my will and charged me more electronic fee. I feel my neck stuck in somewhere that I could not air my voice out to deny it as I don't have any choice but pay whatever I am asked for to complete my degree. Anyone have an idea to raise our voice?
column10:
My daughter just got charged $50 per credit HOUR per class that is online. Guess what? All of them are online because every single one was switched to online after she had registered for in person. So now my tuition bill is an extra $750!! For shame #texasstateunive
rsity Way to go full on cash grab during a global pandemic.
column11: I am disgusted to be a student right now. This behavior and blatant disregard for students is repulsive and makes me ashamed at my choice of university
column12: All fees should be waived. Athletic fee::: administrative fee::: even medical fees. For 4 years::: I never went to your doctors for any medical assistance so should I pay it. I have my own medical insurance.
column13:

column14: Thanks for waiving 342$ in on campus fees::: but charging 600$ in online classes fees... that’s pretty thoughtful of you.
column15: Ima put this on tik tok and make it go viral. 🙄
column16: How is this fair::: TXST::: that a student can sign up for 15 credit hours of in-person courses and YOU decide that ALL of those courses will be online only::: and YOU decide that all on-line courses will require an extra fee? My student had her last course switch just yesterday to on-line only and is now frantically searching for ANY of her courses to be available at another time/date that she can switch to just to avoid SOME of the fees YOU are opting to charge. There is no way that there are fixed on-line learning costs per student that add up to the amounts you are charging given that enormous amount of students that are being forced on-line. Shame on you::: TXST::: for trying to profit from the misery of this pandemic.

column25:
I am not happy with TxState fee reconstruction.
It is about to start the fall semester and I got the email from them to add more fee to the tuition for online classes. How does it make sense? The school needs to work harder to maintain their financial income over the pandemic::: and their students have to figure out how to pay their tuition and keep their student status even their family have lost their job::: but the school wants those student to pay more to maintain their dream profit to satisfy all the their board. If they still offer face-to-face classes::: they are supposed to expect more incurring cost such as sterilizing the room after each class::: and also for their shuttle system to make sure the safety for their students::: and so on. And switching to online classes will help them save those cost. On top of it::: building the online courses is also one of their future steps to expand their education for online degree::: and also reduces the cost to maintain their physical facilities for students and staff. I really want to go protest against those changes. It is selfish.

24) update said: "... based on a holistic analysis of key factors such as number of tests administered::: percent of positive tests::: active cases::: hospitalizations::: recovered cases::: geographic concentration of cases::: prevention methods::: testing capacity::: and contact tracing capacity." column12:
As far as I know::: dorm capacity has not been reduced in a majority of dorms. According to the CDC: IHE On-Campus Housing Settings

Lowest Risk: Residence halls are closed::: where feasible.
More Risk: Residence halls are open at lower capacity and shared spaces are closed (e.g.::: kitchens::: common areas).
Highest Risk: Residence halls are open at full capacity including shared spaces (e.g.::: kitchens::: common areas).

COVID-19 is mostly spread by respiratory droplets released when people talk::: cough::: or sneeze. It is thought that the virus may spread to hands from a contaminated surface and then to the nose or mouth::: causing infection. Therefore::: personal prevention practices (such as handwashing::: staying home when sick) and environmental prevention practices (such as cleaning and disinfection) are important principles that are covered in this document. Fortunately::: there are a number of actions IHE administrators can take to help lower the risk of COVID-19 exposure and spread.

China's new Hong Kong national security law expands across the world

It is not just Hongkongers who are affected by the new so-called national security law. According to China::: it's everyone in the world.

Article 38 says that this Law shall apply to offenses committed against #HongKong from outside the region by a person who is NOT a permanent resident of Hong Kong.

And article 29 says that people who “provoke hatred” towards the Chinese regime or Hong Kong government could be given a life sentence.

Therefore this law affects not only Hong Kong residents::: the 80:::000 American citizens::: or the 30:::000 UK citizens living in the region... But even foreigners who live outside of Hong Kong can be charged for things like speaking at a pro-Hong Kong rally::: writing an op-ed article criticizing Beijing::: or pushing for sanctions against China.

Such people are at risk if they travel to #China or simply transfer flights in Hong Kong.
Experts say the law is even broader than China’s own criminal legislation.

George Washington University law professor Donald Clarke wrote that Beijing "is asserting extraterritoria
l jurisdiction over every person on the planet."

The safety::: health & wellbeing of all Bobcats is our top priority during these unprecedented times. As a result::: experts on campus have worked together to develop the Roadmap to Return. This guideline charts our path for keeping our community safe & students successful. For summer II & fall 2020::: students & families can expect:

- Face coverings will be REQUIRED indoors & outdoors on TXST campuses unless the individual is alone.
- While many summer II courses & fall 2020 courses will be held face-to-face::: we are expanding our offerings of online::: remote or hybrid format courses.
- Social distancing measures will be implemented in classrooms & public spaces.
- Students will have increased access to more spaces with reliable computers & internet services to aid them in their education goals.

Families & Bobcat community members can learn more about the Roadmap to Return here: https://bit.ly/3g04j9X

I have sent an email to the university asking about the number of course offerings for the basic Accounting courses::: specifically. Other majors besides Accounting majors are required to take basic accounting. Yet::: in the fall::: only one course (which is listed as an honors course) was offered on Tuesday/
Thursday. The other classes were on MWF. All together::: these classes only enrolled about 550 students which makes it difficult for many students to get into these. It states above in the Roadmap: "While many summer II courses & fall 2020 courses will be held face-to-face::: we are expanding our offerings of online::: remote or hybrid format courses." This doesn't appear to be the case for the accounting classes::: or any of the other courses I have looked up.

Will they be forced to self-quarantine
for 14 days?
What happens if they live in a dorm?
Will they need to be sent home?
Will all of the students and teachers that they came in contact with need to self-quarantine
?
Will students be wearing masks in the dormitories? In the dormitory bathrooms? In the dining halls?
Will tuition be refunded if a student becomes so ill that they are unable to attend class for several weeks?

This information NEEDS TO BE PUBLICIZED.
IT IS THE RIGHT of every student and parent to understand what the course of action will be when the virus begins to spread on campus.

column81:
If you go through these comments::: you can see what an impossible situation Texas State is in. Half are saying "if you go all online::: I'm dropping:::" and the other half is saying "if you make me come to campus::: I'm dropping." The University is trying to figure out how preserve enrollment while keeping students as safe as possible. You all are angry::: I get it. How about you do something::: and pick up the phone and call your state representatives
::: who are part of a legislature that has continually slashed the budgets of state institutions of higher ed every year since the 08-09 financial crisis. The university has already had to cut the management and operations budgets of every department 50% since this pandemic started::: then they had to go back and cut an additional 10% from every department's overall budget. Now::: the state is informing all agencies that they will be taking an ADDITIONAL 5-10% over the next three years. This isn't President Trauth's fault. It is the lack of priority we place on higher education. Call your state representative:::
and demand that they start responsibly funding the institutions that educate their populace. Then the university may be able to afford a potential 20% drop in enrollment::: which would be CATASTROPHIC to the University.
column82: The safety and well being of students and faculty was blatantly disregarded when administration neglected to collect data from faculty and students on whether they are able or willing to return to in person instruction in the fall. column1:
Dear Students::: Faculty::: and Staff:::

It is difficult to find the words to share this news with you. Today::: I learned that one of our students::: Justin Howell::: was critically injured in a protest in Austin on Sunday::: May 31.

What was already a heartbreaking situation has hit painfully close to home. We are thinking of Justin’s family::: friends::: and classmates during this time and hope for his full recovery and healing.

We are in the middle of a national emergency centuries in the making::: and people are crying out to be heard. The headlines::: the videos::: and the experiences of our community are overwhelming to watch::: and now one of our own in the Texas State family has been gravely hurt.

Black Lives Matter. It is not debatable at Texas State. Justin Howell’s life matters. Black lives matter in our classrooms::: on our campuses::: and in the streets during tumultuous protests. They matter every moment of every day::: no exceptions::: no debate. I am committed to the struggle for their dignity::: humanity::: rights::: voice::: and safety.

Sincerely:::

Denise M. Trauth
President

column1:
A message from the President:

Dear Members of the Bobcat family:::

I have watched with great sadness the situation in Minneapolis related to the death of George Floyd. I grieve for his family::: friends::: and community. While I may never know the personal fear this brings to many of you::: I am enraged with you. And::: I am all the more committed to making Texas State University a place where you can find healing and solace.

In times like this – when our nation’s attention is turned to the destructive toll racism takes in our communities – we are reminded of how critical it is that we remain steadfast in our commitment to advancing a Texas State culture of equity and inclusion.

I hope we all pause::: reflect::: and consider the impact of these events on our Bobcat family and those members hit hardest by this tragedy. Please know that we are here for you and our hearts are with everyone hurting in Minneapolis::: nationwide::: and here at home.

Sincerely:::

Denise M. Trauth

column4: I called the school today::: no one can seem to give me an answer on what day and time my daughters virtual graduation will be. column6:
As a proud Bobcat parent it makes me very disheartened to say that I am NOT at all proud of TXST for deciding NOT to honor your graduates with a ceremony!
My daughter has given 5 hard years of her life to you and is now feeling deflated and heartbroken by your decision.
As a child who was raised without a father::: she was fortunate to have a very loving and supportive Grandfather in her life. There was nothing he wanted more than to see his granddaughter walk the stage as a college graduate. Unfortunately her Grandfather succomed to Stage 4 brain::: lung and bone cancer this last September. She struggled to continue with school through this loss but always said she was determined to walk the stage with "I did it Grandpa" bedazzled on her cap to honor him::: knowing that he would be so very proud of her. That thought kept her hanging on to get through her last semesters.
Now you've made a decision to NOT allow her this and it is beyond sad to hear her speak of a university she was so proud to be a part of like it was just another thing in her life that let her down.
Local Texas high schools and our governor have decided to resume in person classes this August::: yet you can't seem to reverse your decision to allow your graduates to walk that stage so that their families can celebrate this huge honor with them. I honestly think it's disgusting that you have no problem taking our money for five years but can't take a few hours out of your time to honor our children!
I know I am not alone in my thoughts as I signed a petition that was circulated by one of your students that had already gained over 8000 signatures by the time I signed it.
There are hundreds of ways you could alter the ceremonies to aid in social distancing measures::: ways in which I'm sure most people would be more than willing to deal with. Since our governor has lifted restrictions::: why not leave it up to the decision of the families as to whether or not they choose to attend? After all the hard work these students have put in to earn their degrees::: I would hope that you're not just being lazy by not wanting to make the effort to alter ceremonies in order to allow them to take place.
Come on Texas State University... do the RIGHT thing and reinstate graduation ceremonies that were due to take place this fall

column1:
A message from the President:

Dear Bobcats:::

When the decision was made to move classes to remote delivery after spring break to protect our Texas State University community from the spread of the coronavirus::: we also decided to postpone spring commencement to August 6 and 8::: 2020::: to coincide with August 7::: 2020::: summer ceremonies.

The commencement feasibility work group::: which included student representatives::: faculty senators::: a dean representative::: the registrar::: the commencement coordinator::: the associate vice president for academic affairs::: and the chief medical officer::: has searched for the safest options to hold commencement events for more than 6:::000 graduates and their families and friends over three days of ceremonies. After exhausting every possible scenario::: we have made the hard decision that it will not be possible to hold in-person commencement ceremonies in August 2020 for spring and summer graduates while adhering to the required social distancing measures. Instead::: we will share virtual commencement ceremonies on August 6::: 7::: and 8::: 2020.

As President::: Commencement is my favorite time of year. Like many of you::: I am disappointed that we cannot come together in person to celebrate this special occasion. However::: I take comfort in knowing that we are doing the right thing to protect our Bobcat family and the greater San Marcos community.

I know this may feel like a diminished experience::: but by no means does it lessen the accomplishments of our graduates. Commencement is important because it is the ceremony to celebrate and formally recognize the degrees you have earned as graduates of Texas State University. No matter what form commencement takes::: those degrees are yours now::: and for the rest of your lives.

Planning is underway to ensure we have a very special experience to honor our graduates during a virtual commencement. We want to honor our brave students who persevered and graduated despite the disruption caused by the pandemic.

To our graduates::: I offer you a sincere and heartfelt congratulations. Your dedication and tenacity have shown the world what it means to be a Bobcat.

Sincerely:::

Denise M. Trauth
President
column3: I am highly disappointed in Texas State.... myself along with other students have dedicated time ::: hard work and money towards our schooling and this is how our semester will end? No thank you::: We all expected better than this. Yet y’all are allowing hundreds of students even Incoming FRESHMEN to attend class and thousands of students to walk around campus. Ofcoarse::: the school enforced this just so it can receive tuition from students..... smh. The fact that this school fails to at least make special arrangements is sooo disappointing. There could have been limitations in guests (2-4 people ) per graduate along with social distancing seating across the football stadium or basketball arena. Everyone attending could have also been required to wear masks and hand sanitizer. All us have had a tough semester and we will leave Texas state with no special recognition ..... wow. Throughout our four years we have waited for this day and now it has been taken from us and our parents::: so easily like it means nothing. Myself along with other graduates will remember this::: what a shame 😔😭
column4:
I received the email 10 minutes before my LAST and FINAL presentation at Texas State::: and had to hold back tears during. Disappointed to say the least.

I’ll be jumping in Sewell this weekend to celebrate!! Hopefully I’ll see other fellow graduates.
column5:
As an alum::: I'm really disappointed that this is how little effort you've taken to take care of these students. You certainly took their money and they'll be in debt for decades::: but you can't go the extra mile to provide them with an opportunity to walk the stage?

Preposterous. There are dozens of safe ways that you could make this happen by simply splitting majors up a little differently and doing the ceremonies outside in smaller groups throughout the summer and into the fall.

Not as proud as I usually am to be a Bobcat today. My peers deserve better.
column6: This announcement could have been made at the conclusion of finals. Making this announcement while students aren’t even finished with the spring semester is distracting and shows tremendous lack of empathy
column7:
So disappointed and heartbroken for these students who have work so hard and looked forward to being able to walk across the stage and receive their diploma. Large high schools are able to accommodate a live ceremony::: but Texas State can’t? These students deserve this and should be allowed to experience it.
Summer 2 classes are still being held on campus????? But graduation ceremonies can’ t happen for safety reasons.....ple
ase explain.
And two weeks later the campus is resuming the fall semester as normal???
How is a graduation ceremony endangering everyone::: but face to face classes and everything will return to normal two weeks after the scheduled graduation. I am sorry::: this makes no sense and these deserving students are being robbed of a ceremony they have worked so hard for. They deserve the recognition!
column8: President Trauth::: you’ve made some questionable decisions for this university during my time here but this one is by far the most disappointing of all.
column9: A hard pill to swallow::: but we accept it. We are very sad for our Texas State graduate 👨‍🎓::: but understand that the safety and well-being of others is more important.
column10:
Although I do see the big picture::: I do believe this decision was made too soon.

How is TXST going to have Summer II in person?! Why can’t you spread out the graduations by colleges within a week or two week span??

As a first generation college graduate getting a Master’s degree::: quite frankly I don’t care what day of the week I’d walk as long as I get to walk. I’ve spent too much money::: time::: and effort into this degree and this moment to not get to do it.

Please reconsider.

column194:
As a proud Bobcat parent it makes me very disheartened to say that I am NOT at all proud of TXST for deciding NOT to honor your graduates with a ceremony!

My daughter has given 5 hard years of her life to you and is now feeling deflated and heartbroken by your decision.

As a child who was raised without a father::: she was fortunate to have a very loving and supportive Grandfather in her life. There was nothing he wanted more than to see his granddaughter walk the stage as a college graduate. Unfortunately her Grandfather succomed to Stage 4 brain::: lung and bone cancer this last September. She struggled to continue with school through this loss but always said she was determined to walk the stage with "I did it Grandpa" bedazzled on her cap to honor him::: knowing that he would be so very proud of her. That thought kept her hanging on to get through her last semesters.

Now you've made a decision to NOT allow her this and it is beyond sad to hear her speak of a university she was so proud to be a part of like it was just another thing in her life that let her down.

Local Texas high schools and our governor have decided to resume in person classes this August::: yet you can't seem to reverse your decision to allow your graduates to walk that stage so that their families can celebrate this huge honor with them. I honestly think it's disgusting that you have no problem taking our money for five years but can't take a few hours out of your time to honor our children!

I know I am not alone in my thoughts as I signed a petition that was circulated by one of your students that had already gained over 8000 signatures by the time I signed it.

There are hundreds of ways you could alter the ceremonies to aid in social distancing measures::: ways in which I'm sure most people would be more than willing to deal with. Since our governor has lifted restrictions::: why not leave it up to the decision of the families as to whether or not they choose to attend? After all the hard work these students have put in to earn their degrees::: I would hope that you're not just being lazy by not wanting to make the effort to alter ceremonies in order to allow them to take place.

Come on Texas State University... do the RIGHT thing and reinstate graduation ceremonies that were due to take place this fall
column195: DUMB! DUMB! DUMB! I want to know how they came to this conclusion 3 months in advance. They aren’t even giving the seniors a chance!!
column196: All of the students worked so hard and the only option you can come up with is to cancel it. There’s got to be something that can be done. You have huge outdoor stadiums and other rooms that could be used. Please reconsider😡!!!!
column197:
President Trauth::: I hope you see this post. My daughter is a Senior::: or at least she thought she was until today! You see she changed her major a couple of years ago. She faithfully met with advisors going into every semester so that she was on track to graduate p. Our family does not have a lot of money and she has worked 3 jobs while taking 15-18 credit hours each semester. She is even on the Deans List. At the start of this school year she was not told that a class she needed was only offered in the fall. That did not stop her::: she met with the professor and on top of her load he let her do an independent study as she was already working for the City of San Marcos promoting downtown. She is short 1 class that she was going to take in the fall but she was told that she could participate in the graduation ceremony for summer. Our family made plans::: took off work::: reserved hotels. Now you are not having a graduation::: it was a let down but we still kept our plans to watch whatever virtual ceremony there is going to be. But now she received a message that she can not participate! I called her counselor
S office::: the commencement office and your office for an explanation. WHY WOULD YOU CHANGE THE POLICY 4 WEEKS BEFORE GRADUATION!! I can’t believe this! I will no longer recommend TEXAS STATE to anyone! I hate myself because I already convinced my niece and nephew to go and it is to late to change. You obviously do not care about these students::: you have already gotten their money and now feel that you can just throw them away. I guess it is true that people feel UT and A&M are higher quality schools::: you are definitely proving that!

column199:
👨‍🎓👩‍🎓Just spoke to a parent of a graduating 2020 OU student and a 2020 Tech student. The schools decided early on to do virtual for May and in person in August - they could choose to do one or both. Texas State DID NOT come up with the best solution for these students that have worked their tails off for 4 years and gave thousands of dollars to the school - to do a Virtual graduation and to look at what - The President or Dean's speak for a hour? OU's virtual::: apparently you had to find the 13 second link that announced your name. There are many other ways to figure this out::: and YES::: Texas State this may cost you thousand of dollars to spread out the 6:::000 graduates with their families AND still protect the Bobcat family and San Marcos community. Unfortunately::: it makes it very hard to feel your sincere and heartfelt congratulations
when you and the team of individuals came together to make a decision based on facts that you truly don't have for the upcoming August commencement. This virus::: along with the flu and every other sickness is going to be around for awhile -\-\ eliminating the May commencement was a heartbreak::: but took it as it was in the midst of state shutdowns::: etc....BUT to go ahead and make a decision AGAIN to eliminate in August when the state is opening businesses::: restaurants::: etc. -\-\ let the 2020 Graduating Class and their families decide if they want to attend either by Virtual or In-Person::: they have earned this right to do so. A solution::: someone mentioned is needed and plenty of individuals have commented on excellent solutions. So re-collaborate and come up with a solution to spend the money that these graduates have given you all these years (as there is probably a way to turn it in to the Government); give THEM the option to have an In-Person commencement in May::: August or December (spread it out - and I'm sure some would still make a May date); can't have it indoors::: have it at the stadium that seats 30:::000 people (more than enough room). There ARE excellent solutions -\-\ I personally DO NOT feel like ya'll exhausted every possible scenario especially when other universities seem to have found other ways to honor their graduates! Be a dear::: Miss President Denise Trauth::: and show the world what it means to be a Bobcat!! 👩‍🎓👨‍🎓 UPDATE: https://
gov.texas.gov/

organization/

column1:
TXST is proud to announce that the Bobcat Promise program has been expanded to support an even greater number of Texas families and students who are facing financial uncertainty caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. Bobcat Promise will now reach thousands of more incoming Bobcats who have a family adjusted gross income (AGI) that does not exceed $50:::000 annually. This is a substantial increase from the previous limit of $35:::000.

The program will provide undergraduate tuition & fees to eligible fall 2020 freshmen who meet the AGI qualification::: and who submitted their FASFA and were admitted to Texas State by March 15.

TXST will continue making greats strides in our efforts to ensure college is accessible for all Bobcats who need the support.

Read more: bit.ly/BobcatPromise

We are deeply saddened to learn about the passing of San Marcos Police Department officer Justin Putnam (B.S. 2011) on Saturday night. Officer Putnam and two of his fellow officers::: who are now in critical condition::: were ambushed while responding to a domestic disturbance. On behalf of the entire Bobcat Alumni Family::: we want to extend our gratitude to these brave officers for protecting the San Marcos community and our deepest condolences to their loved ones.

Today::: TXST learned that a student tested positive for COVID-19 on March 30. The student returned to campus with a parent to move out on March 27. The student was asymptomatic at that time & did not have close contact with anyone other than the parent.

The student has had only mild symptoms thus far & we hope for a quick & complete recovery. Out of respect for the individual’s privacy::: we are only sharing identifying information with public health officials.

Full statement: txstate.edu/coronavirus

column1:
An announcement from Dr. Gene Bourgeois::: Provost and VP for Academic Affairs::: about Summer 2020 Courses and Summer/Fall 2020 Registration:

I hope everyone is doing well and adapting to remote and alternative course delivery for the spring semester. Texas State University is here to support our current and future Bobcats during this time of disruption. I’m pleased to announce today that we are providing emergency financial aid and adjusting the delivery of Summer I courses to better meet your needs during the COVID-19 crisis.

To make summer 2020 courses at Texas State as accessible as possible while ensuring the continued safety of our students::: faculty::: and staff::: we will move scheduled class sections that start meeting at any point in June to online/remote delivery::: and return to face-to-face and online classroom delivery for the Summer II session (July 6 – August 5). Please note that the decision regarding the Summer II session could change according to public health advice and conditions.

Making the decision now to move Summer I to online/remote delivery gives you the ability to plan accordingly for the future during these still uncertain times::: and allows students to continue toward reaching their educational goals.

I want to be clear: Summer courses are not canceled::: only moved to online/remote delivery for the Summer I session.

Registration for the Summer and Fall 2020 semesters will open on April 6::: 2020.

Here is what you need to know about moving Summer I courses to online/remote delivery:

- Financial aid processing is not directly affected. Remember: The Pell Grant is available for summer classes based on student eligibility.

- Students will be awarded emergency financial aid of $50 per semester credit hour.

In addition::: New Student Orientation sessions will be held virtually this summer. We will provide more information soon about how to participate.

Thank you for your patience as we find the best solutions to help keep you safe and your academic pursuits moving forward.

Full announcement: https://bit.ly/39x6K0d

column1:
A message from Dr. Gene Bourgeois::: Provost and VP for Academic Affairs::: about Spring 2020 Final Grades:

As part of the transition to remote instruction for the spring 2020 semester::: Texas State University will make a temporary change to the final grades policy. This change will provide students with the option to request modification of final course grades to the “EP” (emergency pass) grades. The modification request may only be utilized for courses in which the student earned a passing grade. See the University Registrar’s definition of grades: https://www.registrar.txstate.edu/our-services/grades.html.

The decision to allow this flexibility is in direct response to the unprecedented situation created by COVID-19. The university’s remote courses will continue to maintain the highest quality standards. Students are expected to participate in class activities::: assessments::: and assignments throughout the remainder of the semester. As usual::: faculty members will assign final grades to students using the criteria and performance standards outlined for the course.

Once final spring 2020 semester grades are posted::: students will have until Monday::: May 25::: 2020 to submit a written modification request to their professor(s) requesting an EP grade. Upon approval::: the professor will make the grade change. To be considered::: all requests must be made in writing to the professor by the stated deadline. The modification request option is limited to spring 2020 courses only. Students make requests on a course-by-course basis.

Students are encouraged to consider the consequences of an EP grade::: including those for prerequisite course requirements::: GPA calculations::: GPA minimums for certain programs::: academic standing::: admission to other programs or universities::: financial aid::: veteran’s benefits::: scholarships::: and other academic matters. Students should contact their academic advisor or academic program coordinator for specific questions. Graduate students are strongly encouraged to consult with their graduate advisor about the impacts of an EP grade before seeking a modification request.

Faculty members are encouraged to be flexible but have the authority to make their own decisions on these requests. Decisions by faculty members are due by Friday::: May 29::: 2020. Faculty will use the Change of Grade Web Application for making grade changes to EP: https://tim.txstate.edu/changeofgrade/.

Students may appeal a faculty member’s decision using the procedures outlined for the department::: school::: or college in which the course is taught. The appeal process is applicable for all grades::: including those under review by this temporary change to the final grades policy.

I realize this has not been an easy transition and thank you for your patience and understanding as we assess options and make decisions in the best interest of the university community.

column1:
TXST Registration Delayed:

Bobcats::: we know you are excited to register for summer & fall 2020 courses. Due to the COVID-19 outbreak::: we are delaying the start of summer & fall registration by one week to April 6.

In this ever-changing environment::: we want to be sure we have enough time to make decisions that are best for your safety::: your education & your future. Thank you for your patience & understanding as we plan for the future.

Registration for summer & fall 2020 begins at 7 am on April 6.

Check out the University Registrar's website for more info about holds::: registration errors & time tickets: bit.ly/3apa0fp

📞 512.245.2367
✉️ registrar@txstate.edu
